sec.title: Benthic community patterns and the composition of feeding types and reproductive modes in freshwater nematodes
sec.p: Iris C. MICHIELS ∗ and Walter TRAUNSPURGER
Department for Animal Ecology, University Bielefeld, Morgenbreede 45, 33615 Bielefeld, Germany
Received: 4 October 2004; revised: 17 November 2004
Accepted for publication: 19 November 2004

sec.title: N/A
sec.p: Summary – We characterised benthic invertebrate community composition in 11 oligotrophic, alpine lakes. Nematodes were the most abundant benthic taxa in most lakes but community composition differed markedly. Several relationships between the invertebrate taxa were found but there was no strong evidence that competition or predation shaped the benthic community structure. Most lakes were dominated by a few nematode species with cosmopolitan distribution. Obligate and/or facultative parthenogenetic species were most abundant. With increasing species richness, the overall sex-ratio increased and the relative abundance of parthenogenetic species decreased.

sec.title: N/A
sec.p: Keywords – abundance, alpine lakes, biodiversity, biomass, sex-ratio, trophic composition, zoobenthos.

sec.title: N/A
sec.p: The aim of our study was to analyse invertebrate communities of 11 alpine lakes. The nematode assemblages were identified to species and we examined their species richness, diversity, trophic composition and sex-ratio. The specific questions addressed in this study are: Are there general patterns in benthic and nematode community structures in alpine lakes? Are there relationships between benthic taxa with a similar food niche, indicating competitive or predator-prey interactions? Are higher species numbers (higher numbers of species interactions) correlated with an increased proportion of sexual reproduction within the community and within single species?

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: STUDY SITES

All alpine lakes were oligotrophic with a maximum depth of < 20 m and size ranging between 1 and 60 ha ( Table 1 ). The lakes receive their water through ice and small alpine streams, except for Froschhausersee which is spring-fed. The geology of most catchment areas is limestone.
SAMPLING AND IDENTIFICATION

Ten randomly sampled replicates were taken from the littoral of each lake between 4-7 June 2001. The uppermost 4 cm of the sediment layer was collected using a modified Kajak corer with an internal section of 5.31 cm 2 . All samples were fixed in formaldehyde (4% final concentration) and the organisms were extracted using the silica gel method (Ludox TM 50, mesh size: 35 µ m) modified from
. All benthic taxa from each sample were counted and identified under a stereo-microscope (40 × magnification), after staining with Rose Bengal. Samples containing more than 200 nematodes were subsampled using a sample splitter. From each sample, 100 nematodes were selected randomly for identification, cleared in a glycerol-ethanol solution, stored in anhydrous glycerol, and prepared on microscope slides. Nematodes were identified to species level, following
and
,
). All other invertebrates were identified to coarse taxa. Sediment was sieved through a 63 µ m sieve to determine the clay content. Organic dry weight was determined by incubating the sediment at 105
◦
C ( > 4 h). The loss of ignition was measured after incubation at 490
◦
C ( > 6 h). Sediment carbon was assumed to be 50% of loss of ignition (
).
BIOMASS CALCULATION
NEMATODES
DATA ANALYSIS

To examine for relationships between invertebrate abundance/biomass and abiotic parameters ( i.e ., organic carbon, lake size), and between invertebrates, correlation analyses were performed using Spearman rank coefficient. To estimate whether there was a negative interspecific relationship which could reflect competition within and among nematode feeding groups, we related their abundance and biomass. Further, the relationships between nematode species richness or specific population density and the nematode sex-ratio were examined.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: BENTHIC COMMUNITY STRUCTURE

The mean invertebrate abundance and biomass per lake, as well as of selected benthic groups is given in Table 2 . The composition of benthic organisms varied strongly between lakes ( Fig. 1 ). Benthic abundance tended to be greater with increasing organic carbon content (
rS = 0.57; P = 0.06) but was not significantly related to lake size (
rS = − 0.14; P = 0.69). The wide range of benthic abundances was due to the high variability in two taxa: tardigrades (varying by a factor of ca 50), and nematodes (varying by a factor of 45). Nematodes were the most abundant taxon in seven lakes, whereas tardigrades dominated in two lakes, and rotifers and crustaceans dominated only in one lake ( Table 2 ). Despite the low individual biomass of the nematodes, they reached the highest biomass of all invertebrates in six lakes, whereas crustaceans had the highest biomass in three lakes, and oligochaetes in two lakes. Benthic biomass was neither affected by lake size (
rS = 0.24; P = 0.47) nor by organic carbon content (
rS = 0.32; P = 0.34).
NEMATODE COMMUNITY COMPOSITION AND DIVERSITY

A total of 38 nematode families with 157 species were identified (Appendix 1). Species numbers ranged from 24 to 75 ( Table 2 ). The family Monhysteridae dominated in seven lakes (21-74%), whereas Rhabdolaimidae reached the greatest densities in Soiernsee (42%) and Ferchensee (44%). Tobrilidae dominated Lake Rehbach (29%) and Desmodoridae were most numerous in Lautersee (56%) ( Fig. 2 ).

All 11 lakes had only three species (
Eumonhystera filiformis
,
E. longicaudatula
and
Tripyla glomerans
) in common. A few species usually dominated the nematode communities ( Fig. 2 ), and six to 34 species contributed up to 90% of total density. A large proportion of species occurred in very small numbers only. Lake Vilslache and Lake Rehbach had the greatest diversity. In contrast, the lowest diversity was found in the lakes Wildensee, Lautersee, and Schmalsee ( Table 2 ).
TROPHIC COMPOSITION

Table 4 shows the relationships between abundance and biomass between trophic groups. The positive correlation between plant and hyphal as well as between bacterial and epistrate feeders could be due to similar food sources. Omnivorous nematode abundance and biomass were positively correlated with the abundance and biomass of all other feeding types (except for the biomass of epistrate feeders). Therefore, no evidence was found that nematode prey abundance and biomass were affected by the presence of omnivorous nematodes.
REPRODUCTIVE PATTERNS

Most species found consisted of females (18-60%) and juveniles (38-81%). Relative male abundances varied between 0-9% among the lakes. The sex-ratio variation of abundant species is given in Table 5 . In most bacterialfeeding species, no males were found, while in all three omnivorous species at least in some lakes males were present. Overall sex-ratio increased in lakes with more coexisting species (
rS = 0.69; P = 0.018) ( Fig. 4a ). The overall relative abundance of ‘parthenogenetic’ species (species without males in the investigated lakes) per lake did not decrease with an increasing number of coexisting species (
rS = − 0.44; n.s.). However, within the feeding types, the expected relationship was found in bacterial feeders (
rS = − 0.65; P = 0.029; Fig. 4b ), and was absent in omnivores (
rS = − 0.21; n.s.) and epistrate feeders (
rS = − 0.04; n.s.). In hyphal (
rS = 0.80; P = 0.003) and plant feeders (
rS = 0.64; P = 0.034), the relative abundance of ‘parthenogenetic’ species increased with the increasing number of coexisting species but abundance and species richness in these feeding types were low and the significance of these results is limited. Absolute nematode density had no effect on the sex-ratio (
rS = − 0.04; P = 0.66). Therefore, it can be assumed that biotic interactions through increased species richness enhanced the production of males in facultative parthenogenetic and sexual species.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: BENTHIC COMMUNITY PATTERNS
NEMATODE COMMUNITIES
TROPHIC RELATIONSHIPS

The analysis of nematode feeding types showed a high dominance of small bacterial feeders in most lakes, which appears to be characteristic for oligotrophic habitats (
). Bacterial, epistrate feeders and omnivores were only represented by one or two very abundant species per lake. Algae and plants were scarce because samples were collected at the beginning of the vegetation period and this may be the reason for the low densities of plant, hyphal and epistrate feeders. However, epistrate feeders dominated in Lake Lautersee, probably due to the high density of periphyton on macrophytes, colonised by unicellular eucaryotes and diatoms.
SPECIES RICHNESS AND REPRODUCTIVE MODES

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: The investigated alpine lakes showed a general pattern in invertebrate community structure typical for oligotrophic freshwater habitats. The organic carbon content was the only abiotic factor influencing the benthic community composition. Several relationships between the invertebrate taxa were found. In benthic systems omnivory is widespread and links the dynamics of interacting species. This could prevent strong regulations through competition and predation. The higher sex-ratio and decreased rate of parthenogenesis in more speciose systems compared to less speciose systems could indicate that competition plays a role in natural nematode assemblages, but whether competition or predation shaped these alpine community structures cannot be answered without further experiments.

sec.title: Acknowledgements
sec.p: Many thanks go to Erna Gardner, Nico Michiels, Jenny Schmid-Araya and Hubert Spieth for helpful comments on earlier versions of the manuscript. We thank Nico Michiels for carrying heavy backpacks with sediment samples in the mountains. The study was supported by the German National Merit Foundation.
